text:
Cournot's model was an early version of what are called strategic games, decision models
in which the best choice for a firm depends on the actions (reactions) of other firms. A
more general model of this strategic game was developed by Nobel Prize winner John
Nash, who developed the concept of a Nash equilibrium. A Nash equilibrium is reached
when the choices of all firms are such that there is no other choice that makes any firm
better off (increases profits or decreases losses).
